title: Aberdovey Walks

images.title: Mike White / Dunes, Aberdovey
images.caption: These dunes shield Aberdovey Golf Course from the sea. Beyond them, to the left, a caravan park, then the white houses of Aberdovey itself.

images.title: OLU / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: This square consists of just dunes and sand, much of which is covered at high tide. Looking approximately south, towards Ynyslas across the Dovey Estuary.

images.title: OLU / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Penhelig Arms. This is a very old hostelry and the food and beer are good. A painting in the bar shows sailing ships drawn up on the shore on 'this' side of the road.

images.title: Mike White / Penhelig Arms, Aberdovey
images.caption: Penhelig Arms pub in the town

images.title: Richard Law / NW towards Aberdovey Bar
images.caption: NW towards Aberdovey Bar. Just about on the edge of the bar at Ynyslas, looking towards a group of anglers. The tide needed to go out quite a bit more to expose much of the sandbank at Ynyslas.

description: The town of Aberdovey (Aberdyfi) is located in a lovely position on the west coast of Wales. There's lovely walks along the estuary of the River Dyfi and the coastal path. This walk follows a section of the Wales Coast Path from Aberdovey to the town of Tywyn , just to the north. The route runs along a flat, beach side path for about a distance of about 4 miles. On the way there's lovely beaches, sand dunes and fine views of the Snowdonia mountains in the background. In Tywyn you can also get a direct train back if you prefer not to walk. The Dyfi Estuary is also a nature reserve and a great place for wildlife watching. On the walk look out for osprey and otter in the summer months.
